Molto.definition: Comes before other terms; e.g. molto allegro ("very cheerful")

Assai.definition: Comes after other terms; e.g. allegro assai ("very cheerful")

Più.definition: Comes before other terms; e.g. più mosso ("more moved/agitated")

Poco.definition: Comes before other terms; e.g. poco diminuendo ("a little diminishing")

poco a poco.definition: "Slowly but steadily." Comes before other terms; e.g. poco a poco crescendo ("increasing little by little")

ma non tanto.definition: Comes after other terms; e.g. adagio ma non tanto ("not quite at ease")

ma non troppo.definition: Comes after other terms; e.g. allegro ma non troppo ("not too joyful")

Meno.definition: Comes before other terms, such as meno mosso ("less moved/agitated")

Subito.definition: Comes before or after other terms; e.g. subito fortissimo ("suddenly very loud")

A cappella.definition: Sung with no (instrumental) accompaniment, has much harmonizing

Aria.definition: Piece of music, usually for a singer

Aria di sorbetto.definition: A short solo performed by a secondary character in the opera

Arioso.definition: A type of solo opera or operetta

Battaglia.definition: An instrumental or vocal piece suggesting a battle

Burletta.definition: A light comic or farcical opera

Cadenza.definition: A florid solo at the end of a performance

Cantata.definition: A piece for orchestra and singers

Capriccio.definition: A lively piece, free in form, often used to show musical skill

Concerto.definition: A work for one or more solo instruments accompanied by an orchestra

Concertino.definition: A short concerto; the solo instrument in a concerto

Concerto grosso.definition: A Baroque form of concerto, with a group of solo instruments

Fantasia.definition: A musical composition or “idea” typified by improvisation

Intermedio.definition: A short connecting instrumental movement – an intermezzo

Libretto.definition: A work containing the words to an opera, musical, or ballet

Opera.definition: A drama set to music for singers and instrumentalists

Opera seria.definition: An opera with a serious, esp. classical theme

Oratorio.definition: Large musical composition for orchestra, choir, and soloists

Pasticcio.definition: A musical piece containing works by different composers

Ripieno concerto.definition: A form of Baroque concerto with no solo parts

Serenata.definition: A song or composition in someone's honour. Originally, a musical greeting performed for a lover

Soggetto cavato.definition: A musical cryptogram, using coded syllables as a basis for the composition

Sonata.definition: A composition for one or two instruments in sonata form

Verismo.definition: A genre of operas with scenarios based on contemporary everyday life
